text: hello today we're going to talk about
noun
Clauses before we talk about noun
Clauses we need to talk about nouns and
the three jobs that a noun has so the
first thing a noun can do in a sentence
it could be the subject of a sentence
could be the object of the sentence
could also be the object of a
preposition let's look at an
example first let's look at this
video hey how is school
today so the question what did he
say okay so I here is the noun here his
answer his answer was difficult to
understand in this situation answer is
the noun it's the subject of the
sentence a noun could also be the object
of a verb here I have I didn't
understand his answer answer is the
object of the verb and then a noun could
also be the object of a preposition
here I was
confused about his answer about is the
preposition answer is the object of the
preposition so these are the three jobs
of a noun and a sentence could be the
subject could be the object of the verb
could be the object of a
preposition now we'll move on to talking
about noun Clauses before we go any
further let me just explain a clause is
a subject verb combination so a noun
clause is a subject verb
combination that acts as a
noun so if we remember this sentence his
answer was difficult to understand
answer is the subject I have just about
the same meaning with this what he said
was difficult to understand
in this situation what he said is a noun
clause I have what the question word and
the subject he and the verb said so that
whole Clause what he said is the subject
of the sentence the subject of the verb
was and that situation it's the subject
of the
verb uh one thing to point out about
noun Clauses is that the form is a
little bit different from questions if
you look at my question here what did he
say for people learning English this is
very difficult because we have the
question word and then we have the
helping verb did and then the subject
and then the main verb what did he say
students work very hard to get that
pattern correctly
because they have to put the helping
verb before the subject okay so the
regular order for questions question
word helping verb subject main
verb with a noun
clause it's a little bit different if
you could see first here's my question
what did he say with the noun clause it
is what he said so it becomes the
question word the subject and then the
verb so after they've worked very hard
to get this pattern they need to come
back and get this pattern for noun
Clauses question word subject then
verb let's take a look at noun Clauses
in other parts of the
sentence uh let's look at the noun
clause as the object of the
sentence I didn't understand his is
answer and that situation answers the
object and here I didn't understand what
he said what he said is the object of
the sentence it's a noun
clause okay now we look at the noun
clause as the object of the
preposition if we look at this sentence
I was confused about his answer about is
the preposition answer is the object
object I can use a noun clause to get
the same idea I was confused about what
he said about is the preposition what he
said is the noun
clause let's look at another
example um based on another video this
is the video of where did he go
hey are you finished in
there
hey
what oh no where'd he go where'd he
go yes the question where did he go who
knows so where did he go is a question
has the question word where the helping
verb did the subject he the main verb go
I can change that to a noun clause I
don't know where he went where he went
is the object of the sentence and it's
the object of the verb
no let's try one more example
uh I have the question what does he eat
for breakfast I have is the question
helping verb subject main verb what does
he eat and when I change it to a noun
clause what he eats for breakfast is
unhealthy so in this situation I have
the question word what the helping verb
he or the subject he and then the main
verb eats
that was a brief introduction to noun
Clauses and how they work in sentences
thank you very much
